title: 110_s539
content: The Act may be cited as the "Helping Our States Through Tourism Act of 2007" or the "HOST Act of 2007". In the 12-month period ending on June 30, 2005, tourism was a significant industry in Louisiana and Mississippi, employing thousands of workers and generating substantial tax revenue and economic impact in both states. Louisiana generated $14 in revenue for every dollar spent on tourism, while Mississippi generated $12. Hurricanes Katrina and Rita severely impacted Louisiana's travel and tourism industry, reducing direct traveler expenditures by over 18% from $9.9 billion to $8.1 billion, and travel-generated employment by 9% between 2004 and 2005. Hurricane Katrina also had a severe impact on Mississippi's travel and tourism industry, reducing direct traveler expenditures by over 18% from $6.35 billion to $5.2 billion, and travel-generated employment by nearly 18% from 126,500 jobs. The Gulf Coast economy suffered a significant decline in travel-generated employment between 2004 and 2005, dropping from 126,500 jobs to 103,885 jobs. The revitalization of the tourism industries in Louisiana and Mississippi is crucial for the region's full recovery. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, disaster area, Hurricane Katrina and Rita disaster areas, and major disaster. The Act defines key terms such as Administrator, disaster area, Hurricane Katrina and Rita disaster areas, and major disaster. Relevant tourism entities are defined as convention and visitors bureaus, nonprofit organizations, or other tourism organizations eligible for grants. Small business concern is defined as per the Small Business Act. The Act defines key terms and relevant tourism entities eligible for grants. The Secretary of Commerce will establish a grant program to promote travel and tourism in Louisiana and Mississippi. $130,000,000 will be allocated to Louisiana and $45,000,000 to Mississippi. The funds must be used to promote travel, tourism, and approved economic development activities. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the State, has approved a grant program. States can use their own criteria for awarding grants and are not required to apply federal eligibility criteria. Up to 1% of funds can be used for administrative expenses. $175,000,000 is authorized for this program. SEC. 5. ECONOMIC INJURY DISASTER LOANS. The Administrator may provide a loan to a small business in a disaster area heavily reliant on tourism, which suffered economic injury due to reduced travel post-Hurricane Katrina or Rita. Loan applications must be submitted within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums necessary for this section will be appropriated as per the Administrator's discretion. SEC. 6. FEDERAL GULF COAST TRAVEL AND MEETINGS FUND. Establishment of the Federal Gulf Coast Travel and Meetings Fund in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of appropriated amounts and interest earned on investments. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing the Trust Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Secretary may obligate available sums in the Trust Fund for specified purposes. The Federal Gulf Coast Travel and Meetings Fund in the Treasury of the United States allows for funds to be used for lodging, meals, travel, and other expenses related to large gatherings in the Hurricane Katrina and Rita disaster areas with at least 100 Federal employees. Funds cannot be used for Federal investigations, court cases, or events with less than 100 Federal employees. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations by December 31, 2007, detailing the remaining balance in the Trust Fund, expenditures made, and information on denied requests from Federal agencies. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,500,000 for fiscal year 2007 to be deposited in the Trust Fund. Additional information may be required by the Committees on Appropriations of the Senate and the House of Representatives.
